title: AHA Scientific Statement 2026: Classification and Management of Ischemic Stroke in Patients With Active Cancer

recommendations.text: Coordinate neurology-oncology shared decision-making for AIS in patients with cancer, weighing prognosis and risks/benefits of diagnostics and treatments.
Anticipate a growing burden of cancer-associated AIS as cancer survivorship increases; plan systems of care accordingly.
Active or prior cancer increases AIS risk; risk varies by cancer type, stage, histology, genomics, and treatments.
Primary prevention: aspirin or anticoagulation has not shown AIS risk reduction in cancer; observational data suggest statins may reduce risk in some groups.
After AIS, 1.5%-10% are diagnosed with incident cancer within 1 year; risk is higher with elevated D-dimer, cryptogenic mechanisms, or multiterritorial infarcts.
Compared with noncancer AIS, patients with cancer tend to be older, have fewer traditional risk factors, higher severity, and more widespread infarcts with thrombosis/inflammation markers.
Cancer-associated AIS shows platelet/coagulation/endothelial activation, NET formation, and circulating cancer or platelet-derived vesicles.
Multiple pathways contribute to cancer-related AIS; no single prevention target is sufficient.
Conventional mechanisms (cardioembolism, atherosclerosis) account for about half of AIS in active cancer; cancer therapies can mediate these mechanisms.
Remaining cases are undetermined or cancer-specific; many cryptogenic cases may reflect covert NBTE; stroke from cancer drugs is rare and drug-class specific.
Extend the AIS diagnostic evaluation in cancer with D-dimer and consideration of blood cultures, right-to-left shunt testing, TEE, chest CT, and prolonged rhythm monitoring.
Use the proposed cancer-related stroke classification (probable/possible/unlikely) and categorize as 'other determined cause' when criteria are met.
Reassess goals of care periodically and integrate palliative care alongside disease-targeting therapies.
Consider IV thrombolysis using standard criteria with added vigilance; check CBC/coagulation and generally avoid IVT if brain metastases are present.
Consider thrombectomy for LVO on an individualized basis, incorporating cancer prognosis, goals of care, and procedural risk/benefit.
Cancer-related AIS has high recurrence risk (2-3x; 14%-29% at 1 year) with a U-shaped risk over time after cancer diagnosis.
Tailor prevention to mechanism: antiplatelet therapy and risk-factor control for small-vessel disease, DOACs for nonvalvular AF, and statins for most patients.
When mechanism is absent (ESUS/possible cancer-related), equipoise exists between anticoagulation and antiplatelet therapy; evidence is insufficient to favor one.
